 REPUBLIC OF COTE D'IVOIRE RURAL LAND MANAGEMENT AND COMMUNITY INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT PROJECT 1. INTRODUCTION 1.1 Over the past thirty years, development in C6te d'Ivoire has been accompanied by a progressive degradation of natural resources. Rapid population growth of 3.4 percent annually in recent years has increased pressure on resources. Land, water, forests, and wildlife have been compromised and agricultural productivity has not kept pace with rapid population growth and immigration from neighboring countries. Poor health, low education and insufficient nutrition have fostered poor use of natural resources and inadequate maintenance of infrastructure, common property and open-access assets. Insufficient investment capacity for infrastructure has hindered access to markets, which in turn has limited capital availability and the potential for investments to preserve land productivity. 1.2 Today in West Africa, 18 different donors are supporting a total investment of about US$450 million in over 80 initiatives that are demonstrating that sustainable natural resources management and rural development can best be undertaken through local-level, broad-based community development plans and participatory partnerships with local groups to finance and manage local initiatives. The foundation for the success and long-term sustainability of these efforts lies in appropriate land tenure, decentralization and community empowerment policies. 1.3 The Rural Land Management and Community Infrastructure Development Project (PNGTER) will help create the enabling environment for sustainable rural development by supporting the implementation of suitable land tenure, decentralization and community empowerment policies. It will then provide resources to complement local capacity to invest, presenting local people with a range of alternatives while taking into consideration local experience, skills and social organizations. 2. BACKGROUND A. THE ECONOMY 2.1 With a population of approximately 14 million and a 1995 GDP of US$9.8 billion, C6te d'Ivoire is one of the principal countries in the CFA franc zone. The country is now emerging from a dozen years of difficult internal adjustment. C6te d'Ivoire has been in recession since 1986 and faces a severe external debt problem. High population growth rates and economic decline have led to a steady decrease in living standards. Per capita GNP was well over US$1,000 in the early 1980s. By 1994, it had fallen to an estimated US$5 10. In 1995, it was US$610.
 2 2.2 Cote d'lvoire's economic and social crisis began in the early 1980s, partly as an outgrowth of the surge in public spending following the 1975-77 cocoa and coffee price booms. In 1994, despite several attempts at stabilization and adjustment, the country still faced increasing economic and social problems. Confronted with the deteriorating economic situation, the Government of Cote d'Ivoire along with its partner countries in the CFA franc zone decided to realign the parity of the CFA franc to the equivalent of 100 CFA franc to I French franc, effective January 12, 1994. Following the CFA devaluation, the Government introduced a new stabilization and structural adjustment program for 1994-96 in a policy framework paper discussed in March 1994 by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank. The new program was supported by the IMF through an arrangement under the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) and by the World Bank through several adjustment credits. 2.3 The first year of the post-devaluation adjustment program successfully reigned in inflation, and stimulated growth and external flows. By the end of 1994, inflationary pressure subsided and the increase in consumer prices was contained to 32.5 percent. Overall tax revenue exceeded programmed levels, the wage bill and other current expenditures were under control, and public investment expenditures exceeded the programmed level. The shift in demand towards local goods and a strong positive response by non-traditional exports raised real GDP growth to 1.3 percent for the year despite the impact of lower real wages on private consumption. 2.4 C6te d'Ivoire is heading for a period of political and economic stability. In October 1995, the incumbent president was re-elected. In November 1995, parliamentary elections led to reappointment of the Prime Minister. Municipal elections were held in March 1996, which involved all political parties. The Government successfully exploited the opportunities created by the devaluation. The stabilization program and structural reforms turned around a previously recession-plagued economy. Economic growth accelerated from 1.7 percent in 1994 to 7 percent in 1995, the highest in the CFA franc zone and among the highest in Africa. 2.5 Despite recent positive developments, financial concerns still dominate the economy and the dialogue with financial partners. The country's external obligations still exceed the resources it can currently mobilize internally or externally. During FY 1994-1996, IDA approved new credits totaling US$557 million, of which US$195 million have already been disbursed, with 85 percent of IDA support in the form of fast-disbursing operations. The present project supports the Government's effort to put more resources behind economic development and poverty alleviation. B. POVERTY 2.6 Despite recent improvements in Cote d'Ivoire's economic performance, 37 percent of the population live in poverty. Poverty has worsened considerably since 1987, when the economy declined following a sharp appreciation in the real exchange rate and a deterioration of the international terms of trade. In 1985, 11 percent of the population in C6te d'lvoire was poor (with per capita incomes of less than 144,800 CFA franc per year, about US$290). It is estimated that between 1989 and 1993 household consumption diminished by 24 percent. The proportion of households living in poverty rose to 37 percent in 1995. 2.7 Deteriorating standards of living are reflected in the country's social indicators. C6te d'Ivoire ranks 136th of 173 countries according to the UNDP Human Development Index -- 23 places lower than its ranking on a GDP per capita basis -- indicating that the country lags badly in promoting social development. Negative trends in service indicators, such as availability of safe drinking water, school enrollment and use of medical services, have been prevalent for a decade, causing concern that outcome
 3 indicators will be at risk in the future. Malnutrition, child mortality and illiteracy rates have risen to the point that C6te d'lvoire's social indicators are often no better than those for lower income neighboring countries. 2.8 Poverty is primarily rural in C6te d'Ivoire. The preliminary results of the ongoing poverty assessment confirm that 75 percent of all poor and 69 percent of the extremely poor are concentrated in rural areas. All rural areas are poor. The West Forest Region has the highest incidence of poverty with 47 percent of the population defined as poor. The East Forest Region has the highest absolute number of poor people, and the Savannah Region has the highest incidence (16 percent) and largest absolute number of extremely poor. As a group, over half of foodcrop farmers are poor and over one-third of export crop farmers are poor. Urban poverty has also increased, from almost zero in 1985 to 25 percent in 1995. Though urban jobs are scarce, limited rural income-earning opportunities have fueled urban migration. 2.9 Access to basic education has been particularly limited for the poor. Primary school enrollment is 34 percent in rural areas; it is 57 percent in urban centers. School enrollment is lowest in regions with the highest concentration of poverty. Gender inequalities are particularly apparent in rural areas where females have a lower school enrollment rate, a lower rate of achievement, less access to wage employment and lower earnings. 2.10 After years of denial, the Government now recognizes the poverty problem, and is committed to its alleviation. To bring about a gradual reduction in the absolute number of poor, special programs focused on the poor, particularly women and children, are now being developed. Agricultural productivity must be raised and land tenure security enhanced if poverty is to be tackled. Environmental investments must preserve and enhance the country's natural resource base, emphasizing the land, water and forests on which the poor rely most. Infrastructure development must be accelerated, focusing on the rehabilitation of facilities such as schools and dispensaries, and the introduction of approaches that lower the cost of services for the poor. 2.11 The proposed Project concentrates its efforts in the rural areas where poverty is highest. Its investment support will favor the participatory activities, production systems and types of small-scale infrastructure the ongoing poverty assessment identified as most relevant to the poor and other vulnerable groups. C. THE RURAL SECTOR 2.12 Agro-ecological Regions. Cote d'Ivoire has a rich and varied natural resource base. It is located in the humid/sub-humid zone with average annual rainfall ranging from 900 mm in the North to 2,500 mm in the South Coastal Zone. This natural resource endowment has the potential to allow for great diversification of food and export crop production. It is estimated that about 53 percent of the country's total land area of 320,000 km is suitable for rainfed agriculture and that about 6.5 million hectares (ha) are currently cultivated, i.e., 38 percent of total cultivable area, if gazetted forests and national parks are excluded. With a total rural population estimated at 7 million (1992), average population density in rural areas is 22 persons/km2. The population is unevenly distributed; many areas in the Forest Region already suffer from population pressure that exceeds land potential, given prevailing agricultural technology. The country can broadly be divided into two primary agro-ecological regions with different farming systems and demographic characteristics: the Forest Region and the Savannah Region. These two regions are separated by a Transition Zone. With rainfall between 1,200 mm and 1,500 mm, the Transition Zone has less clearly defined geographical boundaries than the other two regions. It enjoys
 4 higher rainfall than the Savannah Region, but rainfall patterns are erratic and less predictable. Agriculturally, this is the most challenging zone with the highest occurrence of crop loss due to drought or flooding. 2.13 The Forest Region in the south has higher (1,200-1,800 mm) and more reliable annual rainfall and soils of fairly good quality. In the past, the favorable agricultural base and low population density induced a steady influx of farmers from the Savannah and neighboring Sahelian countries. About 530,000 farms out of the country's estimated 830,000 (64 percent of total) are located in the Forest Region. The average farm household has 10 members. Farms average 10-13 ha of land, including forest and fallow. Coffee and cocoa dominate the region's economy. They represent more than two-thirds of cultivated areas. Other tree crops include oil palm, rubber and coconut. Annual food crops account for about 25 percent of the region's total cultivated areas; maize, rice, yams, cassava and plantain predominate (generally inter-planted with cocoa). Agriculture is based upon traditional, manual, land- extensive, slash and burn practices, and yields are low for all crops, except for industrial rubber, oil palm, pineapple and banana plantations. Extensive low-input low-output agricultural practices combined with rapid population growth have led to large-scale deforestation. Increased population density has also induced a gradual shortening of fallow periods, which are now inadequate to permit the restoration of soil fertility. Until recently, land availability and high returns from coffee and cocoa enabled forest farmers to steadily expand land holdings through sharecropping arrangements. Localized land constraints have led to migration rather than attempts to intensify agriculture. With diminished land availability, however, continued land-extensive farming is no longer possible. 2.14 The Savannah Region in the North (180,000 km2) has more limited agricultural potential. While rainfall (900 mm to 1,200 mm annually) is generally sufficient to permit rainfed agriculture, soils with acceptable agricultural potential represent less than 50 percent of total area. Savannah farming is dominated by rainfed food crops (maize, rice, yams, groundnuts) in pure or mixed stands. About 40 percent of the farms in the region (130,000 out of 300,000) produce cotton, the region's main cash crop. Tree crops (mango, karite) and livestock are also significant sources of income. Household size is about the same as in the Forest Region (10 persons), but the average farm size is smaller (3.5 ha), reflecting higher labor requirements for the crops grown and the difficulty of attracting seasonal labor. Land cannot be cultivated for more than two to three years in a row and yields are low. About 15 percent of Savannah farmers and one-third of cotton growers use animal traction. Mechanization would entail significant investments, with up-front costs to be amortized over a long period of time. 2.15 Agriculture. Agriculture has been and will continue to be the main driver of economic growth in C6te d'Ivoire. Between 1960 and 1980 real value added in the agricultural sector increased by nearly 4 percent per annum. Cote d'lvoire remains the largest producer of cocoa in the world (an estimated 1.05 million tons in 1995/96), the second largest producer of robusta coffee (220,000 tons) and the third largest African producer of cotton (260,000 tons). The country has the potential to be a large rubber producer; it has the highest yields in the world. Agriculture provides 64 percent of employment, and contributes about 33 percent of total GDP and 66 percent of total export revenue. Of the total cultivated area (6.5 million ha), approximately 50 percent is devoted to export crops (cotton, coffee, cocoa, oil palm, rubber, pineapple and banana) and 30 percent to food crops (maize, rice, plantains, cassava, yams). The remaining 20 percent is composed of other crops such as fiber plants, citrus, and flowers. 2.16 Farmers constitute the vast majority of the rural population. Agriculture is the largest private sector enterprise in the country and the one with the greatest growth potential at the lowest financial risk and investment cost. Agricultural development presents the best opportunities to decrease poverty and generate economic growth. It is estimated that the potential for annual sector growth is 5-6 percent
 5 through the year 2000. It is expected that agriculture will lead national economic recovery, particularly through exports. The Bank-supported Government strategy is to use the agricultural sector as the primary vehicle for poverty alleviation and sustainable economic development. 2.17 Forestry. For a long time (early 1960s - 1980s) forestry was a key sector in the Ivoirian economy. Timber production rose almost fivefold between 1960 and 1980 before declining after 1984. Exports, estimated at CFA franc 110 billion in 1984, had declined to CFA franc 80 billion by 1993. Timber exports earnings are still substantial, and the Ivoirian timber industry remains an important source of employment (about 11,000 jobs in 1993). 2.18 The rain forests of Cote d'Ivoire have been disappearing for the past 30 years at a rate of approximately 300,000 ha per year. Only 2.5 million ha (8 percent of land area) of closed forest remains in the Forest Region. In the Savannah Region only 2.5 million ha of degraded forests and other wooded areas is left. Migrant encroachment and inappropriate logging have reduced the stock of high-quality timber species. 2.19 The timber industry developed under a regulatory regime was designed to promote processing activities. Exporters are required to operate local processing facilities. Eligibility to export is proportional to producer processing capacity. As a result, though the bulk of timber exports (90 percent) are processed products, there is an excess of inefficient local processing facilities (about 80 currently), many established solely to obtain export allowances. 2.20 The 1994 devaluation substantially improved the competitive position of the Ivoirian wood sector. It also created incentives to log second grade species in order to increase export allowances. Commercial logging and deforestation have accelerated, jeopardizing the potential for the timber industry to contribute to long-term environmental stability and economic development. 2.21 Since 1989, with support from the World Bank (Ln 3186-IVC), the Government has attempted to halt agricultural encroachment in gazetted forests and develop sustainable management plans. As a result, new encroachment has been significantly reduced, wood exploitation in gazetted rain forests is extremely limited and efficiently controlled, and a dialogue with local people bordering gazetted forests has been initiated. 2.22 Currently, most commercial logging is concentrated in un-gazetted rural forests, unprotected forest areas on land owned by farmers under customary law. While in principle the trees belong to the farmers, permits are issued to logging firms by the forestry authority, and only a nominal proportion of the value of the standing timber goes to rural communities. Local people have no incentive to preserve and use the forest sustainably. If non-gazetted forest areas are to survive, farmers must perceive the benefits of sustainable forest management. With decentralization, new local governing bodies will give more authority to communities to negotiate the terms of logging contracts and receive compensation directly. It will be important to ensure that local communities perceive the forest as a sustainable source of income and environmental services, and not a short-term opportunity for cash. By helping communities focus on sustainable agricultural and agroforestry systems as part of broader set of natural resource management options, the present Project will help reduce depletion of forests. 2.23 Environmental Degradation. The agriculture-led economic development and liberal immigration policies that prevailed in the 20 years following independence, accelerated migration from Sahelian countries and transformed seasonal migration into permanent settlement. Economic development based upon extensive agriculture and increasing population has led to severe problems.
 6 Closed forests, which covered about 13 million ha at the beginning of the 1960s, today cover only 2.5 million ha. The development of coffee/cocoa plantations has created an agricultural frontier that has moved from east to west as migrants, in the tracks of timber extractors, have systematically penetrated and cleared the rain forest (also encroaching upon gazetted forests). In most productive areas of Cote d'Ivoire further expansion is hardly possible as agricultural land is becoming scarce. 2.24 Cote d'lvoire's biodiversity is a national and global asset. Since independence, the country has established a network of parks and protected areas that provide a fairly complete picture of the various existing ecosystems. Parks and reserves occupy 9 percent of the country's total land area; however, with few exceptions, they are being encroached upon by fanners; their preservation and protection remain un- assured. 2.25 Soil loss through erosion is estimated to be between 10 and 30 tons/ha/yr in the Savannah Region and up to 200 tons/ha/yr in the Forest Region. The coastal zones, which include the last remnants of the rain forests and biodiverse wetlands, suffer from the highest population pressure in the country; they are particularly threatened, especially near Sassandra, Vridi and Abidjan. 2.26 A National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP) was completed in 1995, with a follow-up roundtable held in September 1996. The NEAP addresses key environmental concerns such as deforestation, loss of biodiversity, soil degradation, coastal zone management and water pollution. The present Project is featured as one of the primary instruments for implementation of the NEAP. 2.27 Land Tenure. Formal access to land is regulated by laws that were enacted during the colonial period (decrees: 23 October 1904, 24 July 1906, 8 October 1925, 26 July 1932, 15 November 1935- the primary decrees among 28 laws and regulations enacted after independence). In principle, all land belongs to the State. Land can be given in the form of temporary or permanent concessions or as private property to individuals that make a specific request. The Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources (MINAGRA) issues concessions and land titles. The procedure for gaining formal access to land is too complex and costly for most farmers. As a consequence, only 2 percent of total rural land has been allocated under legal concessions and titles. 2.28 Modern law neither supports nor undermines land occupation in accordance with customary rights. If traditional land occupants want to acquire legal rights to land, they need to make a formal request and follow established procedures. In order to avoid conflicts, legal land titles are generally issued for undeveloped lands for which customary claims are tenuous, not currently exercised or not clearly grounded. Where lands are in use by traditional occupants, titles can only be issued only after negotiations between the customary occupants and legal claimants. A payment is often made to the customary occupant, but this is a practice with no legal foundation. 2.29 Currently, many different types of land occupation co-exist in rural C6te d'Ivoire, often within the same village. They are customary and modern. They include lineage and family ownership, various forms of long and short-term leases, and full-fledged legal ownership. Hybrids of all these forms are most common. These arrangements are increasingly ill-suited to manage land rights acquisition in rural areas. Unoccupied, undeveloped land is becoming very scarce. The informal process for compensating customary occupants provides little guarantee to either the occupant or the legal claimant. Additionally, the cumbersome, expensive titling procedures are inadequate to respond to the increasing demand for land acquisition and titling in rural areas.
 7 2.30 Since 1989, a pilot initiative financed by the World Bank and Caisse Franiaise de Developpement (CFD), known as Plan Foncier Rural (PFR - Rural Land Plan), has addressed land tenure issues, and demonstrated that there is a strong demand for the clarification of land rights in rural C6te d'Ivoire. Through the PFR, village chiefs, lineage heads, farmers and other concerned parties have participated in the identification of rights and mapping of village land and plot boundaries. Overall, the pilot initiative has been extremely well received by villagers, and has not been meaningfully opposed or criticized by any ethnic group, political party, NGO, association or other segment of civil society. 2.31 The PFR pilot operation covers eight zones that are broadly representative of the various land use and land rights scenarios in C6te d'Ivoire. As of October 1996, the operation had completed fieldwork on about 495,000 ha corresponding to 27,300 land plots in 360 villages. Land tenure rights have been clarified for 270,000 people, including migrants, who compose between 5 and 70 percent of the populations of the zones surveyed. The unit costs of the survey and land certification process have decreased with experience and the introduction of technological improvements. Currently, land rights clarification costs CFA franc 3,600 per hectare, which makes it possible to expand operations nationally. 2.32 The PFR has simultaneously charted land use and carried out household and village demographic surveys. These surveys provide a wealth of information on land tenure, tenure claims by migrants, conflicts between transhumant herders and farmers, access to unoccupied undeveloped lands, land grabbing, and the rights of the Government to control unoccupied land. The maps that have been produced are already being used to guide decision-making regarding the location of access roads, transhumance corridors, small irrigation and land management works, and physical infrastructure. The information and experience will be sufficient to determine the legal value of the PFR and lay the foundation for a new land tenure law. Specific proposals were developed by a comprehensive legal study completed in January 1996 as part of the preparation of the present Project. 2.33 A National Land Rights Reform Commission was established in 1993 to start working on a new rural land tenure law. In August 1994, the Council of Ministers stated that the Government intends to extend nationally the land tenure clarification operations launched through the PFR. The statement was strongly endorsed by the donor community at the Paris Meeting of the Consultative Group in 1995. Land rights and the PFR were studied as part of Bank sector work and a 1993 Bank Technical Paper (AFR Technical Paper 238). The PFR was evaluated with French financing in 1994 and in 1996 with World Bank financing. The present Project design is based upon the recommendations of past studies and evaluations as well as supplementary analyses during project preparation. 2.34 Territorial Administration, Decentralization and Community Empowerment. The Country's administrative structure consists of 16 regions, 58 prefectures and 229 sub-prefectures. Before 1990, most technical ministries had their own regional and local organizations which did not necessarily correspond to those of the territorial administration. In 1992, these were reviewed and reconciled; Regional Development Commissions (CRDs) and Departmental Development Committees (DDCs) under the authority of the Regional Prefects were created. The CRDs include representatives of the local administration and technical ministries, elected representatives, village chiefs and members of professional organizations. The CRDs are in charge of establishing, implementing and monitoring regional development plans, including investment programs in the field of rural infrastructure and agricultural development. 2.35 Since independence, the Government has been reaching out to local populations by deconcentrating and decentralizing governance and the provision of services. Deconcentration has involved the delegation of central territorial administration responsibilities to offices located closer to the
 8 populations being served. In urban areas, decentralization has involved the delegation of responsibility for matters of local interest to local entities called "communes" which have autonomous legal status. Their representatives are elected by the local population. 2.36 Since the mid-1980s, 135 urban communes have been created, allowing 50 percent of the country's population to select representatives and benefit from administrative and, increasingly, financial autonomy. Recently 61 urban communes (one per each sub-prefecture) were created. The decentralization experience has been positive. In 1993, 42 percent of communes total revenues were generated from local taxes and fees collected directly. Another 42 percent was generated by centrally collected taxes that were returned to communes. 2.37 Recently, the Government began to focus on expanding the decentralization process to rural areas, and introducing a democratic system for governing local-level planning, decision-making and administration. Law 95-892, which was approved on October 27, 1995 (General Organization of Territorial Administration), established the legislative foundation for decentralization. Law 95-893, approved on the same date, gave legal status to rural villages and groups of villages, and sanctioned their right to be administered by locally elected governing bodies with administrative and financial autonomy. The law also established the authority of the rural communes to formulate Local Development Plans (LDPs) in consultation and collaboration with higher level governing bodies (rural districts, departments and regions). The imminent creation of the first 110 rural communes was formally announced through a communication from the Council of Ministers in September 1996. Despite the favorable legal environment, extension of decentralization to rural areas is bound to be constrained initially by: financial limitations, the absence of functional governing structures at the village level ready to assume governance responsibilities, weak inter-village linkages, and the dearth of procedures and mechanisms by which to facilitate village administration and inter-village cooperation and decision making. 2.38 Rural Districts (pays ruraux) will gradually be transformed into rural communes. Pays ruraux are groupings of 6 to 9 villages that are similar in terms of accessibility and socio-economic profile, with at least 5,000 - 6,000 inhabitants and 300 km2 of land. Pays ruraux were established by the Ministry in charge of planning and finance as a planning unit in the 1970s. In preparation for transition to rural communes, pays ruraux need to be strengthened by the creation of mechanisms and procedures for inter- village decision making and administration. The present Project will help move pays ruraux in this direction. 2.39 The FRAR Program. The Regional Rural Equipment Fund (Fonds Rigionaux d'Equipement Rural- FRAR) was initiated in the early 1970s. It survived the economic crisis because of its appeal to local populations and its success. Between 1972 and 1996, the FRAR channeled CFA franc 52 billion in funds for over 10,000 microprojects for rural infrastructure, including social facilities (83 percent), productive facilities (7 percent) and rural roads (10 percent). In the period 1993-1996 alone, the FRAR supported 3,274 microprojects at a cost of CFA franc 24.4 billion, CFA franc 9.3 billion of which consisted of village contributions. 2.40 The FRAR is one of the main instruments by which the Government and the donor community have agreed to channel resources to promote local initiatives and foster decentralization and community empowerment. The Fund complements financial resources gathered by local populations for priority investments in agriculture, and rural and social infrastructure (village contributions vary from 30 to 60 percent, depending upon the type of investment and the income level of concerned villages).
 9 2.41 The Regional Planning and Development Directorate (DPDR) of the Ministry of Planning and Industry (MDPDI) is in charge of implementing and coordinating the FRAR regionally. The DPDR consists of 10 regional chiefs and 37 field technicians who survey needs, collect village requests for support, evaluate overall costs and government and beneficiary contributions, and supervise the award of contracts, implementation, completion and payment for works. 2.42 Village requests are collected and discussed at annual sub-prefecture and regional meetings organized by the FRAR involving representatives of technical ministries and concerned villages. This approach ensures that proposed works are fully integrated into the programs of ministries, and that adequate budget and staff are planned and allocated to operate newly created infrastructure (i.e., teachers for new schools, visiting doctors and nurses for new dispensaries). Currently, Prefects and sub-Prefects have administrative authority over the selection of initiatives proposed for financing and selecting contractors to implement works. They also directly pay contractors once satisfactory implementation is certified by FRAR technicians. 2.43 Although FRAR has concentrated on the creation of social infrastructure, a wide range of works is eligible for support including land management, bottomlands development, small-scale irrigation, and tree planting for protection and production. The technical standards, specifications and base costs for the eligible types of infrastructure are listed in a catalog that was originally developed with UNDP support and is updated annually. Preliminary identification of infrastructure needs is based upon a matrix that defines the infrastructure required for given village (and pays rural) types. FRAR implementation procedures, which are well known to the rural populations, are currently being updated. They will be integrated into the Project Implementation Manual. The European Union (EU)-sponsored evaluation concluded that the FRAR program is able to efficiently coordinate the implementation of sizable works and ensure cost-effectiveness. FRAR projects such as school construction are about half as costly as similar infrastructure built under other Government or donor-supported programs. 2.44 The general success of the FRAR should not hide some fundamental shortcomings that hamper effectiveness. They include: (a) a rather mechanical approach to village needs, assessments and planning of infrastructure which limits community participation and commitment to proper management and maintenance; (b) a method for calculating village and government contributions that does not necessarily reflect the capacity of communities to participate and the priority given to the various infrastructure investment alternatives; (c) a relative disregard for works such as land management which require more careful planning by and support from well-organized user groups; (d) insufficiently close links among villages in a given pays rural, limiting the incentives for village support of works extending to other areas of the pays rural; (e) insufficient village knowledge of and participation in the award, supervision and payment of contracts; and (f) time gaps between the completion of infrastructure (i.e., hospitals) and the provision of personnel and operating funds by concerned technical ministries and local funding sources. 2.45 Following an EU-financed evaluation, DPDR is improving the FRAR's implementation and funding mechanisms with EU, French and Bank support (through PNGTER preparation). The Project will: (a) help the FRAR foster more community participation in the management and maintenance of newly created assets; (b) strengthen inter-village organizations and links; and (c) enrich the range of possible interventions in order to respond in a more comprehensive manner to infrastructure, land and environmental management needs. In the future, communities will have a larger role in the selection of initiatives to be financed, and in the implementation and management of new assets. The present Project will assist the transition to greater community control.

THE BANK STRATEGY IN THE RURAL SECTOR 2.46 The current Bank strategy in the rural sector has three primary components: (a) the institution of sound sectoral and macro-economic policies and structural reforms; (b) the improvement of production systems, community organization and rural infrastructure; and (c) the implementation of sound environmental management. 2.47 Sectoral Policies and Structural Reforms. These aim at restoring competitiveness and broad- based, sustainable economic growth. The Bank is supporting reforms that remove rigidities in the incentive framework, reduce the market-related functions of the public sector and support efforts to divest and privatize public enterprises engaged in production and processing. In particular, the Bank is helping the Government eliminate or privatize the transport price equalization system, further liberalize the marketing of coffee and rice, and eliminate the commercial functions of Caisse de Stabilisation (CAISTAB). Accompanying the shift in responsibility from parastatals to the private sector is support to agriculture professional organizations for management of entire commodity sub-sectors. The Bank is working with other donors to evaluate options for providing medium-term credit to farmers in a financially and socially sound manner, while continuing to support the formation of small-scale rural savings and loan cooperatives (CREPs). 2.48 Improved Production Systems, Community Organization and Rural Infrastructure. The Bank assistance strategy concentrates on supporting land tenure clarification, community-based land use and rural infrastructure development planning, rural investments, and production and marketing through enhanced agricultural services. The Bank's strategy is to help the Government capitalize on the reorganization of extension services to strengthen research-extension linkages and support the development of a national agricultural research system that is responsive to the needs of farmers. The Bank plans to reinforce the development of the livestock sector by supporting the integration of animal health into the extension services. Support is also envisaged to streamline the functions of the MINAGRA at the central level so it better sustains the decentralized structure in place at the field level. 2.49 Environmental Management and Conservation. Bank support focuses on assistance for NEAP implementation, and national forest resources conservation and management. The NEAP is the framework within which all programs with an environmental dimension will be screened and implemented. Bank-assisted forestry programs will be continued, with an emphasis on conservation, and a stronger focus on improving the incentive structure, logging and land conversion regulations, and concession and fiscal policies. This will help curb deforestation and increase revenues to the Government and rural populations. Core forestry protection, rehabilitation and management programs will continue to be undertaken primarily in State-owned forests which have a higher biodiversity value and, given their land tenure status, are more likely to offer an opportunity for long-term management and preservation. E. LESSONS LEARNED FROM PREVIOUS BANK EXPERIENCE 2.50 In developing the proposed Project approach, 12 past projects in C6te d'Ivoire (3 rubber projects, 2 road projects, 4 agriculture projects and several other rural development efforts), the findings of the Africa Region FY94 Annual Review of Project Portfolio Performance (ARPP) and the Bank's sector work on land tenure were analyzed. Past Bank experience indicates that natural resource management projects should be developed as part of a long-term strategy for development. The Africa Region FY94 ARPP found that projects need to take into consideration cross sectoral issues including structural constraints and policy distortions. For example, the Second Forestry Project (Ln 2496-IVC) would have
 11 benefited from a broader planning process that examined the risk of farmer encroachment. Government policies are particularly important in creating or distorting the incentive environment needed to encourage desired outcomes. To attain necessary policy reform, however, the ARPP, the Agricultural Sector Adjustment Loan (Ln 3127-IVC) and the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Adjustment Loan (Ln 3240-IVC) found that the institutional and political process for policy change needs to be outlined from project inception. Additionally, the Fourth Rubber Project (Ln 2323-IVC) found that in order to attain necessary policy reform, technical ministries as well as the range of other stakeholders need to be involved in policy deliberations. 2.51 A participatory, demand-driven process of project design, and the selection of specific interventions and activities is crucial for long-term success. Natural resource and agriculture projects should incorporate activities that emphasize sustainable use and generate income and employment so that they provide incentives for involving local people in the long term. The Second Grand-Bereby Rubber Project (Ln 1575-IVC), Agricultural Extension Project (Ln 2765-IVC), and Northeast Savannah Rural Development Project (Ln 1827-IVC), all suffered to some extent because they did not select activities and priorities based upon local needs and preferences. Alternatively, the Center West Agricultural Development Project (Ln 2167-IVC) and the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Adjustment Loan (Ln 3240-IVC) both benefited in terms of sustainability by working with and listening to local people and building local support for activities. 2.52 The Second Grand-Bereby Rubber Project (Ln 1575-IVC) and the Fourth Rubber Project (Ln 2323-IVC) would have benefited from more attention to land tenure status and land availability. The success of the Center West Agricultural Development Project's (Ln 2167-IVC) pilot land tenure project attests to the benefit of land tenure clarification in facilitating land administration and local investment in project activities. The Bank's 1993 sector work on land tenure concluded that the approach followed in Cote d'Ivoire is consistent with the thrust of Bank-financed initiatives favoring decentralization and provision of agricultural services and rural infrastructure. The sources of land tenure insecurity should be identified and instruments provided to address them. Additionally, the participatory approach to acquiring land rights should gradually gain full legal significance. Land rights surveys and mapping have limited impact unless they are complemented by institutional reform to facilitate land transfers and enhance capacity to resolve disputes. Not all boundaries have equal importance: clarification and award of legal status to the boundary of the village terroir as a whole should precede and will greatly reinforce, the legal status of the terroir. If the community is to be protected against external private or state interests this is indispensable. Land use data generated from boundary surveys should be used to enhance planning at the local and national level. Land rights clarification alone is not sufficient to generate development: its impact is greatly enhanced when clarification and mapping are accompanied by extension support, investment and other opportunities to enhance farm incomes. 2.53 In order to optimize rural infrastructure such as rural roads, standard models with technical specifications should be used to help plan and manage small road works while ensuring adherence to minimum standards for new construction, routine and periodic maintenance, improvement and rehabilitation. The exchange surrounding the 1992 "Review of Completed World Bank Operations" indicated that existing guidelines such as those in the 1991 paper on "Rural Roads in Sub-Saharan Africa" provide a good framework for operation.
 12 3. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT RATIONALE 3.1 Fundamental demographic and ecological changes have characterized the last forty years in rural Cote d'Ivoire. In 1955, the country had a population of 2.5 million indigenous citizens. Today, there are approximately 14 million residents, 30 percent of whom are naturalized citizens from neighboring countries. Over 80 percent of the closed forests, which covered about 13 million ha in the early 1 960s, have been converted to low input/low yield agricultural land, plantations of perennial commercial crops and unproductive wastelands. Rural areas house over 70 percent of the country's poor. 3.2 Past and ongoing efforts to improve agricultural practices meet infrastructure needs, and slow deforestation has not been fully successful because critical incentives for sustainable land management, human capacity to manage resources and infrastructure, and regimes, for control and regulation are lacking. Land degradation is worsening, and past efforts to decentralize management have had only limited impact. The strength of traditional village regimes of control is decreasing as immigration and population growth increase. New instruments governing access to and management of land are needed. 3.3 Incentives for sustainable land management are inadequate. To maintain output, poor farmers expand the area under cultivation rather than intensifying production. They do so because unregulated access to land renders expansion less expensive than investments to improve land and purchases of inputs such as fertilizer. 3.4 The action and investments required for sustainable management of natural resources and community development are too site-specific, vast and diffuse to be centralized, organized, implemented, finded and maintained by the Government. Past centralized efforts to improve environmental management and community development generally failed because they were sectorally focused, top- down and production-oriented. Communities were inadequately involved in planning and did not maintain investments. Decentralized management and investments in local infrastructure and land management are critical. In principle, authority now rests with communities; however, they have been unable to capitalize on the autonomy because they lack governing structures to manage participation in planning and oversight of resources for investment. 3.5 In order to create a framework for sustainability, the Government, with the concurrence of the donor community, has developed a broad strategy that cuts across sectors. This strategy intends to: (a) create conditions that favor a structured approach to natural resources management using clarification of land tenure as a primary tool; (b) build the capacity of and transfer authority to local organizations, locally elected bodies, decentralized units of technical ministries, and local state authorities; and (c) provide targeted support to organized communities to implement interventions for the development of village land resources and infrastructure. 3.6 To be successful, the above elements need to be addressed in an integrated manner. Beginning with the clarification of local land tenure, the proposed Project will help rural communities assume responsibility for planning, financing and managing LDPs to improve the use of natural resources, accelerate diversification, intensification and growth of agriculture, improve access to markets, and upgrade basic living conditions. The organization and empowerment of rural communities will be key to enhancing self-governance and ensuring the sustainability of programs. Past experience has clearly indicated that while land tenure clarification is essential to facilitating improved land management and
 13 investments, it is not, in isolation, sufficient to generate investments and increase production, especially in the short and medium term. 3.7 A base of policies, instruments and experience has been created in C6te d'Ivoire for clarifying land tenure, decentralizing decision-making, financing village infrastructure and implementing community-based natural resources management. The present Project provides an opportunity to use these instruments and capitalize on this experience in an integrated fashion using existing institutions and local entities as vehicles for implementation. As such, the Project is specifically endorsed by a policy note which was jointly signed by the Ministers of Planning and Agriculture, that was approved by the Council of Ministers, and disseminated to C6te d'Ivoire's donors and partners in development. The note, which was issued as a condition for negotiations, states the role of the Project in support of inter-sectoral policies and related institutional mechanisms (see paragraph 6.2.(a)). B. RATIONALE FOR BANK INVOLVEMENT 3.8 The proposed Project supports land tenure clarification, improved environmental management, rural development, decentralization and poverty alleviation -- all long-term endeavors for which substantial Bank and donor community resources are needed. Each of these areas of activity was highlighted in the assistance C6te d'Ivoire sought from the donor community during the 1995 Paris Consultative Group Meeting. The Bank has a comparative advantage in providing support to the types of activities supported by the Project. The World Bank pioneered support for land tenure operations in C6te d'Ivoire in 1989 and supports comparable village land management programs throughout the region (i.e. Mali, Niger, Burkina Faso, Guinea and Benin). 3.9 The proposed Project fits well within the Government's strategy. It emphasizes those areas that were specifically selected for Bank support in the June 28, 1994 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) and in the June 27, 1996 CAS Progress Report. The CAS update focused on five priority areas: (a) maintaining macro-economic stability; (b) promoting private sector development; (c) increasing the effectiveness of human resources development and poverty alleviation; (d) strengthening institutional capacity; and (e) intensifying environmental work. The proposed Project is important for promoting private sector development, improving infrastructure, and alleviating poverty. The Project is also central in the implementation of the Cote d'Ivoire NEAP, which was developed with Bank support and adopted by the Government in October 1995. 3.10 The present Project has been designed to create a framework for long-term development. As such, it constitutes a critical element of the Bank's support to decentralization, poverty reduction, and agriculture and forestry development. It supports decentralization and community-financed investments in rural areas, while a parallel Project (Municipal Support Project, Cr. 2704 IVC), supports similar activities in urban centers. The Project complements ongoing and future Bank-financed Forestry Sector Projects because it will help organize communities, stabilize agriculture, improve infrastructure and clarify land tenure in areas surrounding gazetted forests threatened with encroachment. The Project will also increase the effectiveness and complement the Bank-supported Agricultural Services Project (PNASA). In fact, it will make the results of land tenure and land use surveys immediately available to extension agents, who will then be in a position to better focus their extension work. Farmer communities, organized with PNGTER support, will also be better able to capitalize on the technical messages of extension agents.

No new project structures will be created, and no adaptation of institutional mandates will be required. Institution strengthening underlies all PNGTER components. Project-supported activities will be integrated into the workplans of existing national institutions and organizations. Existing financing channels will be employed and improved. In line with the Government policy to withdraw from direct implementation of works, support to government institutions will focus on enhancing capacity to oversee and evaluate the efforts of private and non-governmental operators. 3.12 The Project will support government programs formally endorsed as priorities at the 1995 Paris Consultative Group meeting. The Project will also expand the use of participatory planning and management to ensure that investments are made in areas where target populations perceive a need and are willing to cofinance, maintain and manage assets. 3.13 In an effort targeted towards getting results in the field, a large proportion of funds is earmarked for local investments. The selected financing mechanism will maximize the flow of funds directly to primary stakeholders and intended beneficiaries, reducing unnecessary and costly financing procedures and increasing transparency. In order to enhance poverty alleviation, community income levels will be used as a criterion in selecting zones for intervention. 3.14 In order to increase sustainability, the Project will require a minimum of incremental recurrent costs. Project implementation will not require deployment of additional permanent staff by the Government. Most Bank financing will go towards the creation of new assets with minimum maintenance costs and which communities will maintain (the land tenure registry and village infrastructure). 3.15 Procedures for implementation will be outlined in an Implementation Manual that was prepared as a condition of negotiation and will be adopted as a condition for project effectiveness (see paragraph 6.2(g)). The manual will facilitate implementation and ensure transparency. It will be improved and updated over time as experience is accrued. D. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.16 The project will help create the enabling conditions necessary for raising the standard of living of Cote d'Ivoire's rural population by empowering communities, stimulating local investment and facilitating sustainable management of natural resources and rural infrastructure. Its specific obiectives will be to: (a) facilitate land tenure security on over 2 million hectares of rural land by introducing legislation, instruments and procedures to help communities clarify land rights and increase land tenure security; (b) strengthen local capacity to plan, make decisions, govern and manage affairs at the local level; and (c) support small-scale investments for sustainable natural resources management, sustainable agriculture, and infrastructure development that will be undertaken collaboratively by the Government of C6te d'Ivoire and local communities. 3.17 The Project will be implemented in selected areas covering about 10 percent of the country's land area and 18 percent of the rural population. It will be a vehicle for the implementation of
 15 Government policies and programs related to land tenure, decentralization, local self-governance, natural resources management, and rural infrastructure development and maintenance. 3.18 The Project will enhance local management capacity in 1 10 pays ruraux. During the first year of operation of the Project, 43 of these pays ruraux will acquire the status of rural communes. Approximately, 660 villages, with an average population of 2,000 people per village, will be covered by the Project. A total of 1.3 million people, 10 percent of C6te d'Ivoire's population, will benefit from the Project. E. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 3.19 Summary Description. The project consists of an interlocking set of components that are organized to systematically facilitate sustainable community-based management of resources. The project will help consolidate the incentive framework, and strengthen the human and institutional capacity to manage local resources. This will be combined with assistance to develop locally appropriate management plans. Finally, financing and long-term incentives will be made available to ensure that management plans are implemented and reinforce the inclusive planning and management process that has been established. The project will include four components: (a) clarification of land tenure; (b) enhancement of local management capacity; (c) local investments; and (d) support for decentralization and coordination of the project and the environmental mitigation plan. (a) Clarification of Land Tenure. Land surveying, mapping and land tenure clarification will be undertaken to: certify land rights, facilitate conflict resolution, and help identify land management and development options. (b) Enhancement of Local Management Capacity. Based upon the maps and information obtained through the Clarification of Land Tenure component, communities will be assisted to participatorily develop LDPs that outline what is needed to sustainably manage agricultural, pasture and forest land as well as associated water resources, and to develop and maintain village and inter-village infrastructure. Elected rural communes, customary community organizations and interested groups will be strengthened to facilitate self-governance and local management, and maintain newly created infrastructure and income-earning assets. Organizations will be strengthened at the village, pays rural, district and regional levels. (c) Local Investments. Financing will be provided to enhance community investment capacity and implement LDPs. Prerequisites for financing will be: (i) community financial contributions to activities; and (ii) the existence of community organizations capable of helping manage and maintain investments. (d) Support for Decentralization, and Coordination of the Project and the Environmental Mitigation Plan. The Project will provide targeted material support and training to the locally-elected governing bodies created in the process of decentralization. The Project will also facilitate inter-institutional coordination, monitor the implementation of policies and programs launched under the Project, and ensure that the need for environmental mitigation measures is detected and addressed efficiently.
 16 Detailed Description of Project Components 1. Clarification of Land Tenure (US$30.8 million) 3.20 This Project component will be instrumental in securing land rights and developing private and govemment capacity to survey land rights and provide land titles to interested right holders. The component will expand the ongoing PFR, and help set-up long-term institutional arrangements for its continuation and continuous update. The component will consist of two operations: (a) land and land rights surveying, and (b) maintenance and management of land rights information. A detailed description of the technical and legal aspects of this component is presented in Annex 10. 3.21 Land Rights Surveyine. The prime outcome will be the production of maps in paper and digital formats, and of land tenure documents certifying local land tenure status. Current land use, and other demographic and land-related information will be recorded to help guide community and government decision-making about land management, the location of access roads, other physical infrastructure, transhumance corridors, forest boundaries, and small irrigation works. The techniques that will be used have been fully tested. Repeated evaluations have found them to be socially acceptable, technologically adequate and reasonably priced. 3.22 At field level land tenure operations will involve: (a) awareness-raising campaigns targeted at local people, local government officials, and elected representatives; (b) demographic surveys of the people living on or using a given piece of land; (c) studies of local land rights customs and practices, whether traditional or recently introduced; and (d) field surveys of land use and land rights, field by field, in the presence of the land user, the land owner, neighbors and the village chief or other representative of senior citizenry. Survey teams will be composed of an extension agent, a topographer and an interviewer. Surveys will be completed only for lands where no disputes are pending. Following completion of the land rights survey, information will be made public, locally and nationally, and any claimant will be able to register disagreement. After three months without conflicting claims over a given parcel, land tenure status will be considered certified. 3.23 The Bureau National d'Etudes Techniques et de Developpement (BNETD) will manage the survey process at the request and on behalf of the Land Tenure Service of the MINAGRA. The land survey and land rights documentation produced by the MINAGRA will meet the technical specifications and formatting requirement of the Office of Cadaster of the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF), which is responsible for issuing land titles. This will facilitate and reduce the cost of titling if and when this service is requested by farmers. 3.24 Project-supported land tenure clarification efforts will not change current perceptions of land rights, i.e., they will not reinforce land use rights that are commonly regarded as tenuous (i.e., short-term leases) or vice-versa. Experience indicates that for many farmers, recognition of land ownership by neighbors, when supported by a government-sponsored initiative such as the PFR, is sufficient ownership guarantee. For some farmers, mandatory or unsolicited issuance of land titles by a government agency would generate fear of taxes and reduce interest in tenure clarification. 3.25 Survey teams will deposit maps in the relevant regional and central Land Tenure Service offices of MINAGRA. Copies will also be left with the villages and sub-prefectoral offices of the State administration. Land rights registers, indicating village, lineage and pilot boundaries, and recording claims to land as well as current land uses will also be deposited as indicated above. In each village, land tenure information will be maintained by a Village Land Tenure Committee. The updating of land tenure
 17 information by this Committee and by MINAGRA's local Land Tenure offices will have to be verified and validated at the sub-prefectoral level by the Rural Land Tenure Commissions (RLTC) to be established pursuant to inter-ministerial Arrete which was signed prior to Board presentation and to be published in the Journal Officiel as a condition for effectiveness (see paragraphs 6.2.(c) and 6.3 (h)). The RLTC will be chaired by a Sub-Prefect and will include: a representative of MINAGRA, a representative of the national Cadaster, a magistrate, and representatives of local customary and elected authorities. These committees will guarantee the veracity of land tenure documentation produced through the Project and will be empowered to resolve conflicts at the request of local administrative and traditional authorities. 3.26 Over 2 million hectares will be covered in five years. The Project will support the establishment, training and equipment of 10 survey teams, one in each region. Each Land Tenure Regional Survey Team (RST) will have 35 technicians, either contracted individually or in the form of micro-enterprises. Support will also be provided at the central level to ensure centralized purchase of aerial photos, quality control, coordination of field operations, and links with institutional partners Specific social and gender analyses will be undertaken to ensure that the different sets of rights to land are captured by the project. Special attention will be accorded to usufruct holders to guarantee, or at least not to hinder, their security of tenure. Based on considerations of efficiency, the Project will seek incentives and mechanisms to ensure an optimal and sustainable use of land by different stakeholders. To maximize the development impact of the Project, the social assessment and analysis of land related conflicts that was carried out during project preparation will be updated annually. 3.27 Maintenance and Manazement of Land Tenure Data. The long-term success of the land tenure security instruments will depend upon the capacity created in supporting government institutions (primarily the rural Land Tenure Services) and the commitment of villagers to update regularly the land rights record. Though village boundaries are usually fixed, changes in land ownership and distribution inside the confines of the village (among lineage groups and households) take place frequently and will need to be recorded. 3.28 The Project will help create the necessary motivation and technical capacity at the institutional and community levels to ensure that updating becomes routine for institutions and local communities. A pro-active information policy and systematic efforts for training villagers and local authorities will help ensure that updating of land rights records is demand-driven: specialized teams based in the Regional Land Tenure Service offices will respond to requests from local people to update records. Regional Land Tenure Service staff will be trained and equipped to respond to community requests and visit villages semi-annually to monitor changes in land rights. 3.29 The Project will improve and equip land tenure service offices and train Land Tenure Service personnel. ITF support will finance the rehabilitation and equipping of offices, training of personnel and a portion of operating costs. 2. Enhancement of Local Management Capacity (US$6.6 million) 3.30 Support will be provided to strengthen community capacity to identify and address problems, work collaboratively with the State administration and the private sector, and fully engage in the process of decentralization. More specifically, the Project will strengthen village capacity to plan, implement, finance and manage initiatives and development plans at the pays rural level. Work under this component will result in better organized communities capable of using locally available services and funding to develop, co-finance and manage LDPs.

LDPs will specify the actions to be undertaken by community groups, individual farmers and other land users as well as the external support needed. The main steps in the process include: (a) awareness raising and trust-building; (b) needs assessment; (c) facilitation of community organization; (d) design of community-based LDPs; (e) agreement between the community, govermment and other stakeholders; (f) implementation plan; and (g) monitoring. (see paragraph 6.3(c)). 3.33 Participatory needs assessments and village development planning and management will be facilitated by 16 multi-disciplinary support teams (MSTs) that will become operational during the first year of the Project. Formal approval of an LDP will be required at the village and pays rural levels. With the exception of the national level committee, the composition of approval committees will always include representatives of the concerned villages, the Prefect, the Sub-prefect and the relevant technical ministries. The approval process and procedures that will be used were not specifically created for implementation of the proposed Project. While they may appear complex, they are well-known by the local administration and local communities, are mastered by FRAR agents, and have performed fairly well for the past 17 years. The approval process is outlined in Annex 7. 3.36 The Project will work with FRAR to enhance the community role in decision-making, limiting the role of the Prefects and Sub-prefects to act as guarantors of fairness and legality in decision-making and financial transactions. The approval and financing process will ensure that LDPs are consistent and compatible with district, province and regional development plans and abide by state-of-the-art norms, as well as national technical and environmental standards. The process will also permit concerned technical ministries to approve or reject plans and arrange for the timely allocation of any necessary funds and personnel. 3.37 The approval process will also allow proposed actions and investments to be screened for compatibility with Project criteria identified in the Implementation Manual. These criteria will dictate that: (a) supported activities benefit predetermined, eligible target groups; (b) only economically, socially and environmentally sustainable productive activities receive support; (c) the beneficiary community demonstrate its commitment to activities through a matching contribution; and (d) priority be given to activities with relatively long-term economic and environmental returns that communities usually could not afford to implement without external support. The criteria will ensure that the Project does not finance: (a) recurrent expenditures; (b) activities that already receive funding from other sources; (c) activities that may have a negative impact on the environment; and (d) activities that are too complex or demand heavy mechanization. 3.38 The participatory nature of the Project makes it inappropriate to determine in advance the mix of activities communities will adopt and the overall rate of adoption. No specific physical targets are therefore set for specific Project activities. Community interest and the technical/economic viability of various interventions were tested in different agro-ecological zones through village-level consultations with beneficiary communities, agriculture extension and research institutions, the public works department, the FRAR, and others providing funding or services in rural areas. The interventions that appear most likely to attract community interest and absorb the bulk of Project resources are: (a) integrated agriculture production systems such as (i) improved agriculture practices requiring adjustments in the spatial organization of traditional cropping patterns and optimal crop rotations in the drier zones, (ii) improved management of fallow lands and natural tree canopy to improve moisture conservation in the more humid zone; and (iii) integrated agriculture and small animal husbandry in the dry and humid zones. For the past seven years these systems have been tested with satisfactory results by the
 20 Agricultural Research Institute in Bouake. Full scale trials and demonstrations were undertaken with villages that agreed to collaborate. Schemes increased production and environmental sustainability, and were usually accepted and maintained by farmers after termination of collaboration with the research institution; (b) improved agriculture production, forestry and agroforestry interventions such as bottomland development, erosion control measures, small-scale irrigation, fishponds, post-harvest loss reduction, fallow land management, and various family and village- based agroforestry models; (c) small-scale rural infrastructure such as rehabilitation and construction of feeder and access roads, rehabilitation and construction of classrooms, dispensaries, housing for teachers and nurses, and solar photovoltaic equipment. 3.39 It is estimated that on average, the total Project and community resources required to finance LDPs will be equivalent to US$24,000 per community, or approximately US$140,000 per pays rural over a three-year period.
