BENEFITS 5.1 The Project will substantially improve the quality of life of about 1,300,000 people living in I 10 pays ruraux including 660 villages selected on the basis of willingness to collaborate with the Project and relative level of poverty and local infrastructure. The primary benefits of the Project will be: (a) improved land tenure security in the Project area, and established mechanisms, enabled institutions and legal instruments to enhance nationally rural land tenure security; (b) empowered local communities and local community governing bodies, improved local management capabilities, increased local responsibility and ownership of local initiatives, more effective use of community owned resources and of matching resources available through state- and donor-sponsored programs; (c) investments in agricultural production and natural resources management that increase outputs and introduce more sustainable production systems; established sustainable land- use systems that balance production against resource consumption and promote the restoration of ecological stability; (d) investments in rural infrastructure that improve basic living conditions, including access to schools, health services, and clean water; (e) opportunities for private sector developments through over 1500 small contracts to be awarded on a competitive basis to local enterprises, and through the creation of new consulting firms and a market for their services in support of the decentralization process. 5.2 In the longer-term, through the Clarification of Land Tenure component, the Project will reduce conflicts over land, and create a basis for loan guarantees and a land-based taxation system that will facilitate and make more equitable revenue collection in rural areas. B. ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 5.3 The design of the Project was based on the examination of altematives to ensure that the approach and technologies used, and the institutional arrangements selected, would be the most likely to succeed at the lowest cost and level of extemal support. Four different solutions were considered. Socio-economic factors, technologies, institutional issues and management options were analyzed and compared. Resulting scenarios were outlined and debated at national seminars organized under the aegis of the Prime Minister's Office and of the Ministries concerned. The selected scenario was chosen as the most suitable for reducing the administrative burden and ensuring that the greatest possible share of Project resources will flow efficiently to intended beneficiaries, achieving tangible, durable results.
 34 5.4 The economic analysis of the Project started with the financial analyses of 3 integrated farming systems, 13 individual techniques in the field of natural resources management and 8 small rural infrastructure interventions. These assessments analyzed the costs and benefits of several technical options in three representative agroecological zones of the country. The most financially, technically and socially feasible designs were retained for future consideration. 5.5 Several different packages of possible interventions were considered for given socio-economic and agro-climatic situations. The size and values of the packages were kept within the estimated capacity of villages to contribute cash and labor in order to qualify for partnership with the Project. Aggregations of sample activities and packages likely to be chosen by communities were considered on a agro-ecological-zone, community and pays-rural basis. Assumptions about the rate of adoption, and the enabling conditions created by the Project and other Government services (availability of extension, access to markets, availability of inputs) were incorporated into the analysis. 5.6 The data made available through the economic analysis helped shape project design, and define project implementation principles and monitoring parameters that will help ensure the Project's economic viability. One of the key lessons of the economic analysis was that the project should only support packages of interventions that incorporate a variety of different investments, at least 45 percent of which are agriculture-related productive activities and 10 percent of which are non-agricultural productive activities. 5.7 The potential profitability to farmers of investments was assessed in terms of the return on labor and the financial return on investments (both individual investments and packages of investments). In terms of the return on labor, given an average 342 FCFA in salary (economic), the project showed the potential to increase the average rate of return on labor several times. In financial terms, packages of interventions that included the recommended percentages of productive and non-productive activities had financial rates of return between 20 percent and 38 percent. 5.8 In economic terms, all packages of interventions had positive net present values. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for project-supported packages, excluding the costs of capacity building, land tenure clarification and project management, was 38.1 percent. With the addition of these components, the EIRR was 13 percent, still above the assumed opportunity cost of capital (12 percent). Since environmental benefits were not accounted for, it can be assumed that the economic rates of return will actually be higher. When other non-quantifiable benefits such as Government and private sector institution building are added, the project can be expected to have a high economic rate of return. 5.9 The results of the economic analysis are summarized in Annex 13. They are fully developed in a technical report available in the project file. C. RISKS 5.10 The principal project risks relate to: (a) the capacity of the Government to implement the proposed program; (b) the' willingness and ability of communities to collaborate in planning, implementing and funding development plans (c) potential social problems associated with implementing land tenure clarification. 5.11 The inter-sectoral nature of the Project, and the decision to use existing institutions and financing mechanisms are key to project success but entail risks. The project requires the cooperation of the Ministries in charge of agriculture, finance, interior, and planning. While this is a risky proposition, the
 35 activities supported by the Project address the needs of a single target population. By being supported through one funding instrument, these activities will benefit from greater internal consistency, while the costs and risks of duplication will be reduced. The Project has tried to address institutional risks by ensuring that all institutions involved participated actively in project preparation. Project concept, design, documentation and implementation arrangements were produced by an inter-ministerial task force. This arrangement will continue during project implementation. Formnal detailed inter-ministerial collaborative agreements were drafted by the concerned agencies. They have been drafted prior to negotiations and discussed with IDA, and have been signed prior to Board presentation (see paragraph 6.2(a)). The fact that project coordination will be undertaken through the Office of the Prime Minister should help ensure that inter-ministerial cooperation will benefit from the required high-level attention. 5.12 Communities may be reluctant to accept the planning methods and the financing arrangements proposed by the Project. The reluctance of villages in a given pays rural to collaborate was identified as a problem in the implementation of the FRAR. The legacy of the past may also hinder ongoing efforts to make FRAR more responsive to expressed community needs, more transparent and more appreciated by communities. This risk is addressed by devoting resources to support enhancement of community capacity to articulate needs and manage decision-making and financing. This is further addressed by separating responsibility for helping communities identify their needs and formulate LDPs (role played by MSTs) from responsibility for helping them obtain and utilize financial resources (role played by the FRAR). 5.13 The risks that (a) technological packages in the field of agriculture and rural infrastructure may not be readily accepted and (b) that community financing may be lacking are high. The project addresses these risks by (a) using packages consistent with those tested and adopted by ANADER and other relevant national services; and (b) working only with interested groups, involving farmers in the planning and selection of activities, and adjusting the estimated contributing capacity of the communities. 5.14 Other risks may stem from social perceptions and reactions to project support for clarification of land tenure. After seven years of pilot operations involving over 235,000 people in the areas of the country most affected by land tenure conflicts, and several thematic studies on specific issues and target groups, this risk appears limited. The Project will nevertheless monitor social perceptions of land tenure work and introduce necessary corrective measures as problems arise. Annual reviews will systematically focus on land tenure and emerging social conflicts for consideration by the Government, the Bank and other donors. 5.15 The Project involves a significant level of risk but is worthy of implementation. It will yield large environmental and economic returns, channel resources where they are most needed, and leverage and focus additional local community resources on rural development and environmental conservation. D. SUSTAINABILITY 5.16 The Project promotes sustainable agricultural development by focusing comprehensively on production, the impact of production on the natural resource base, and the natural resource base's capacity to sustain production in the long-tern. The most critical factors for Project sustainability are found at the community and national Government levels. 5.17 Community ownership will be the first guarantee of sustainability. LDPs will be prepared with external technical and financial assistance, but decisions will rest ultimately with the communities which will be responsible for financing and managing implementation. Long-term sustainability at the
 36 community level will become possible as improved land use, production systems and technologies are promoted in communities that possess the necessary know-how, and legal, technical and financial tools to properly design and implement plans. 5.18 On the national level, sustainability will depend upon the Government's continued commitment to the approaches and activities of the Project after project termination. This is likely because the Project supports decentralization and land tenure clarification which are, by definition, long-term Government endeavors. 5.19 Recurrent costs represent less than 5 percent of the total cost of the Project during the disbursement period. The Project was designed to emphasize investments and minimize recurrent expenditures for the Government. Implementation support will be provided by local contractual staff, and micro-enterprises. Assistance will terminate once targeted communities have been organized and trained, their management plans designed and approved, and the main investments completed. The Project's fiscal impact is limited and largely absorbed by the communities benefiting from the Project. Details are provided in Annex 13. Following the project's disbursement period, communities will be able to maintain investments and will need only limited additional technical support which can be provided by technical ministries and the private sector. It is estimated that the recurrent costs for communities will be 10 percent of the value of average investments per village per year, i.e., US$2,400 per village, or US$1.20 per capita. The expansion and maintenance of land tenure surveys will not be costly (on a per ha basis) and are highly valued by beneficiaries; in the future, mechanisms could be established to supply this service on a fee-for-service basis. Rural communes, will be established as part of decentralization, will retain administrative and financial autonomy, and possess their own sources of revenues; they will be in a position to ensure maintenance of assets. All communities will continue to be eligible to benefit from Government financing opportunities through the FRAR, though the financing available will be lower after the Project concludes. 6. Bekhechi Technical Specification and Process Reminder of obiectives: This component will be instrumental in securing land rights and developing private and governmental capacity to survey land rights, provide titles to interested land rights holders and manage land tenure information. The component will expand the ongoing Plan Foncier Rural (PFR), increase its efficiency and help establish a long-term institutional arrangements for its continuation and continuous update. It will take stock of techniques tested over a seven year period. Outputs: The prime outcome will be the production of paper maps and implementation of a digital database called a Land Information System (LIS). Current land use and other demographic and land-related information will be recorded to help guide community and government decision-making regarding land management, the location of access roads and other physical infrastructure, transhumance corridors, forest boundaries, and small irrigation works. In a country where large scale mapping is still very poor, this multipurpose cadastral information system will also contribute to many sector development efforts and meet the needs of several users. Process: A chart outlining the critical phases of the production process and the flow of activities is presented on the following page. There are two major operations: (1) establishment of a land information system in new areas, and (2) maintenance and management of land rights information. Establishment of a Land Information System in new areas: (1) This first operation was tested during the PFR and encompasses four types of activities: (1.a) preparation which includes global studies, awareness raising campaigns targeted on local people and establishment of photomaps to support further field surveying, (1.b) land and land rights surveying, (I.c) LIS implementation and map printing and (1.d) publicity, and dissemination of maps and information at the local and national levels. Prevaration (I.a) and field work (I.b): These two activities have been mastered by the PFR regional and central teams. Each team will survey between 400 and 1000 hectares per month, depending upon the type of land. Classical methods of topographic surveying will be used, employing photomosaic or orthophotos at 1:10.000 scale as the background. Each village map will be georeferenced with its absolute coordinate stored in a national database using GPS equipment. Field surveys of land use and land rights will be undertaken field by field, in the presence of the land user, the land owner, neighbors and the village chief or other representative of senior citizenry. Surveys will be managed at the regional level by Regional Offices. Surveys will be completed only for lands where no disputes are pending.

Land Tenure Legislation The fundamental principle of land tenure legislation in Cote d'Ivoire is that all land rights are vested in the State. Current land tenure legislation is largely based upon two colonial decrees from the 1930s which have been modified by post-independence decrees. Legal procedures for obtaining individual freehold title to land are defined in a decree issued on July 25, 1932 saying that private claims and the acquisition of title can be based upon evidence of active land use. A subsequent decree of November 15, 1935 reaffirmed the principle that all unoccupied land belonged to the State, and stipulated the State's right to seize lands if they had not been used for more than ten years. The 1935 decree held that even land in use under customary law could be expropriated by the government given economic justification. In 1955, a decree on May 17 renounced public claims to vacant, unoccupied or unexploited land; in order to stake a claim to land it was necessary to demonstrate that the land was either not subject to customary law or that the customary claimants had waived their rights to the land. In 1957, a decree established expropriation procedures that are still in force today. To implement expropriation procedures, land must be the subject of a definitive grant and must not have been exploited for at least five years. A fair compensation scheme is spelled out in the 1957 decree and 1958 implementing regulation (regulation 8868 of October 28, 1958 outlines the rules for application of decree 57-243, issued on February 24, 1957). Land tenure registration was established under colonial rule and is part of the current land law of C6te d'Ivoire. Despite its avowed support for registration, the government has taken few steps to ease the stringent requirements for acquiring land title that were inherited from the French. Individuals seeking legal possession of land can obtain it either on a temporary or a definitive basis from the State. Temporary concessions such as occupation permits and "concessions subject to claims by a third party" are the simplest and least costly means of obtaining land for private use. The registration process begins by recognizing that no customary rights may be claimed over the land and that land must be registered in the name of the State before it is granted to individuals. Only 12 hectares can be registered at any one time. The remainder of the concession can be leased long-term; therefore, an individual seeking to purchase a large area would have to survey and register the tract in 12 hectare parcels. Alternatively, an individual could purchase twelve hectares and lease the remaining area. After independence, the Government sought to establish the primacy of State rights and modern tenure procedures over customary law. In 1963, a bill declaring that all unused or unregistered land was the property of the State was prepared but never promulgated. More significant, a March 20, 1967 decree declared that "land belongs to whomever exploits it, provided that exploitation rights have been formally registered". The need for formal land registration has never been recognized or enforced, and registration has little significance to residents. The benefits of registration are usually poorly understood by local communities, especially when their land is leased or granted to foreigners. Additionally, definitive land rights ("title") are obtainable only after survey and registration, a time-consuming process that costs more than FCFA 100,000 per hectare. Customary transactions are still pervasive. In practice, all lands remain subject to customary law and any attempt to exploit or develop land must take place with the explicit cooperation of traditional authorities. Old Practices, and new procedures It is commonly accepted in C6te d'lvoire that land tenure security is ensured when a documented claim to land exists and parcel limits are marked. The PFR has been helping to create the basic documentation that can be used to secure land tenure. Data collected by PFR teams have been used to answer questions related to land rights by identifying: (i) the limits of community, lineage and family plots, (ii) the nature of the
 ANNEX X Page 6 of 7 rights enjoyed by tenants and the terms by which they can be transferred; (iii) the lands ceded to foreigners and migrants, (iv) the methods for protecting the rights users, and (v) approaches to resolving conflicts over land. PFR results have shown that under customary tenure, land is primarily owned by groups (family, tribe, lineage) or by overlapping groups, while rights are exercised by individual members of the group. Foreigners sometimes have land rights on an informal basis on land village authorities have given them. Therefore, registration of customary land rights involves certain policy concerns. When adjudicating, the problem is to determine how ownership and rights are divided among the individual, the group and the government. Principles for resolution of the issues must be defined and ambiguities resolved regarding the registration of unused land, the policy regarding group ownership, and the registration of land as "customary land". For unused land (which is very rare), the current legal answer is that these areas belong to the State. For land on which divided and overlapping rights are exercised, it is preferable not to alter the current balance between customary and modern law. There is the common misconception that registration of title is inconsistent with community, lineage or family ownership, and that it connotes individual ownership. Under customary law a "group" can own land. Local communities, especially in the Korhogo region, view land as a collective resource bequeathed from ancestors and held in trust for future generations. The oldest living male member of the village often acts as landlord and allocates land rights. The government, through its local representative (le sous-prefet), allocates unused lands according to law enacted under colonial rule. Customary control and distribution of land among communities is changing. Landlords and lineage chiefs still retain control over land, overseeing a large percentage of transactions including sales, however, land holding rights are becoming fragmented. Nonetheless, very little land is legally transferred according to formal Ivoirian laws. This is generally attributed to the general population's ignorance of the laws and the high costs associated with land registration; no explanation is given for why the State does not enforce land law. Informal and formal land tenure systems currently coexist, introducing uncertainty into the land rights situation. Disputes are frequent in some regions, where it is unclear which rights are being transferred when land is "sold", "granted", "leased" or "lent". Some communities claim that they sell cultivation rights but still possess the land. Others argue that sales are actually short-to-medium term leases and that land must be returned after a certain period. The new legal framework for rural communities (regime des communautes rurales-- enacted through the Law 95-832) will encourage a dialogue involving customary authorities at the village level and government representatives at the local level. In order to reconcile customary and modern dictates, PNGTER will support registration of all land surveyed by the PFR in the name of the Government, and issuance of titles to village communities. This will give rural communities confidence in the Government institutions and create an incentive for sustainable management of land. Village authorities, as described in the Law 95- 892, will be charged to manage and control village land titles; in the future, changes in title will not be allowable without village authorities' acceptance. Long-term divisibility of land title may be allowable based upon a request by members of the village that is endorsed by village authorities and registered by local government representatives. Under the new system, government officials will no longer have the power to give new residents use rights for village lands without the permission of village authorities. Traditional land rights will be reinforced and complemented by the governmental monitoring of land registration and transactions. Land tide registration and issuance will become easier and quicker. After an initial period when it will be free, charges can be levied to compensate for cost incurred by the Government. Overall costs will remain however affordable even for the poorest.

The project will facilitate sustainable community-based management of resources by helping consolidate the incentive framework, and strengthening human and institutional capacity to manage local resources. This will be combined with assistance to develop locally-appropriate management plans. Financing and long-term incentives will help ensure that management plans are implemented and reinforce the inclusive planning and management process established. The project includes four components: (a) Clarification of Land Tenure. Land surveying, mapping and land tenure clarification will be undertaken to: certify land rights, facilitate conflict resolution, and help identify land management and development options. (b) Enhancement of Local Management Capacity. Based upon the maps and information obtained through the Clarification of Land Tenure component, communities will be assisted to participatorily develop Local Development Plans (LDP), that outline what is needed to sustainably manage agricultural, pasture and forest land as well as associated water resources, and to develop and maintain infrastructure. Rural communes, community organizations and interested groups will be strengthened to facilitate self-governance and maintenance of infrastructure and assets (c) Financing of Local Investments. Financing will be provided to enhance community investment capacity and implement Local Development Plans (LDP). (d) Support for Decentralization and Coordination. The Project will provide targeted material support and training to locally-elected governing bodies. The Project will also facilitate inter- institutional coordination and monitoring of policies and programs launched under the Project. The design of PNGTER minimizes potentially negative enviromnental impacts by fostering consideration of social, environmental, economic and cultural factors in community planning and decision making. The holistic planning process fostered and facilitated by PNGTER will result in the creation of sustainable development plans; most of the potentially negative project-related impacts will be avoided or mitigated in the planning process. Prior to appraisal of this project an independent environmental impact assessment was commissioned during which extensive field visits were undertaken, mainly to observe environmental conditions in different agro-ecological zones of the country and to present the project to local communities. SUMMARY OF MITIGATION PLAN COMPONENT SUB-COMPONENTS Environmental information tools * Year 1: Needs assessment, elaboration of methodology, procurement, purchase of equipment * Year 2: Dissemination of village land maps, identification of monitoring plots, training of rural land management teams, purchasing of equipment Elaboration of technical norms * Year 1: Adoption of guidelines for the rehabilitation and construction of rural infrastructures, adoption of guidelines for wetlands and small irrigated schemes Training * Year 1: Training of rural land management teams on environmental issues * Year 3: Training of additional rural land management teams on environmental issues, Elaboration of handbooks * Year 1: Elaboration of a project environmental handbook * Years 2 and 3: Updating of environmental handbook Establishment of demonstration environmental * Establishment of demonstration plots for agroforestry activities and investments and tree shade management Area monographs and sectoral studies * Monographs of first 3 priority areas, study on wetland and small irrigated schemes The demand-driven approach promoted by the project makes it impossible to identify ex ante the specific positive and negative environmental risks that will be engendered in each community. The selection of specific interventions is an important component of the project itself; mitigation of risks will therefore need to be based partly on review and evaluation of the individual land management and infrastructure development plans produced. Additionally, the project proscribes that all community development plans and investments be screened for negative environmental consequences and comply with standard specification that minimize risks.

doc.repnme: Ivory Coast - Rural Land Management and Community Infrastructure Development Project
doc.abstracts: The Rural Land Management and Community Infrastructure Development Project will help create the conditions needed to raise the standard of living of Cote d Ivoire's rural population. Its specific objectives will be to: (1) facilitate land tenure security on over 2 million hectares of rural land; (2) strengthen local capacity to plan, make decisions, govern and manage affairs at the local level; and (3) support small-scale investments for sustainable natural resources management, sustainable agriculture, and infrastructure development to be undertaken collaboratively by the government and local communities. The project will include four components: (1) Clarifying land tenure surveying, mapping and land tenure clarification so as to certify land rights, facilitate conflict resolution, and help identify land management and development options; (2) Enhancing local management capacity- assisting communities to participatorily develop local development plans (LDP) outlining what is needed to sustainably manage agricultural, pasture, and forest land as well as associated water resources, and to develop and maintain village and inter-village infrastructure, strengthening rural communes, community organizations, and interested groups to facilitate self-governance and local management, and to maintain newly created infrastructure and income-earning assets; (3) Financing local investments- financing to enhance community investment capacity and to implement LDPs; and (4) Supporting decentralization, and coordinating the project and the environmental mitigation plan.
